Mark, thanks for the response. I believe that my class path is setup
corre=
ctly, since when i run  
java org.junit.runner.JUnitCore org.junit.tests.Al=
lTests

it passes with no error.

I printed the class path and this is what=
 I got.

C:\junit4.3.1>echo %CLASSPATH%
.;C:\Program
Files\Java\jre1.5.0_06=
\lib\ext\QTJava.zip;C:\junit4.3.1\junit-4.3.1
.jar;C:\junit4.3.1\

Regardin=
g the Java version I got 1.5.0_11 but still it can't recognize
the annotati=
ons for some reason.

Let me know what do you think.

f.s.

> > Ok. Here is whats happening.

der org/junit/samples. I modified the

ried to compile it using javac

st.java:3: <identifier> expected

quals;

rg.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

> The faq (in particular):-
> 
>    http:/=
/junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm#started_2
> 
> includes information =
about setting your classpath to include the
> junit.jar files.  This will a=
llow the compiler to know about the junit
> classes and make them available=
 for import.

Test.java:16: illegal character: \64
> >         @Before public void setUp(=
) {

> What version of java are you using?
> 
> typing :-
> 	j=
ava -version
> 
> at the command prompt will give you this.  Are you using =
a build older
> than 1.5?  If so you need to bring your JDK up to date, so =
it knows what
> to do with annotations (@Before).
